titleInfo.title: Mission Feel!
titleInfo.subTitle: Feeling Emotions, Enhancing Life: A Novel Emotional Understanding Intervention for Preschoolers

mods:mods.abstract: Emotion understanding (EU) is an important competency that children begin to develop during the first years of life and serves as an essential building block for life-long learning. EU is linked to a host of developmental outcomes including academic, cognitive, and social-emotional skills. Not surprisingly, a number of efficacious interventions to promote children's social-emotional learning, including EU, have been developed. Scale-up of these interventions is challenging because they are time and resource intensive. Brief, fully automated interventions that can be accessed at the convenience of participants are a promising alternative for overcoming barriers to implementation of EU interventions. Mission FEEL! is a two-session, fully automated intervention to promote EU among preschool children using a cognitive-behavioral framework. The current proof-of-concept study examined the user acceptability and feasibility of Mission FEEL! to provide an evidence-base for deciding whether to proceed with more rigorous testing of the intervention. I recruited 52 preschool children and their parents/guardians across the state of Florida. Participants completed four virtual study visits consisting of a baseline assessment to measure children's pre-treatment EU, two intervention sessions, and a one-month follow-up assessment. Following each intervention session, parents answered three questions to assess intervention feasibility. At the end of Session 2, parents completed a more thorough acceptability and feasibility assessment. I established a priori benchmarks for evaluating the intervention's feasibility, acceptability, and clinical meaningfulness (80% = excellent; 70% = good; and 60% = adequate). The study results provided support for both the acceptability and feasibility of Mission FEEL!. All outcomes met the benchmarks for good or excellent, apart from two that fell in the adequate range. The clinical meaningfulness of the intervention was supported by parental perceptions of the program's influence on emotion-related parent-child interactions, the perceived value of the program in children's daily lives, and the observed difference in EU scores between baseline and follow-up. Additional factors supporting the intervention's clinical meaningfulness were the low cost and the relative ease of scale-up (i.e., translating the intervention from a local level to a regional and national level). Taken together, the findings from this proof-of-concept study suggest that Mission FEEL! merits advancement to the next phase of intervention development testing.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Christopher J. Patrick, Professor Directing Dissertation; Sylvie Naar, University Representative; Jesse Cougle, Committee Member; Alexandria Meyer, Committee Member; Ashby Plant, Committee Member.
